intro: Polygala vulgaris subsp. pawlowskii, commonly known as the common milk-vetch, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender stems and small, clustered flowers that are often pink or purple in color. The plant has pinnately compound leaves and produces small, pod-like fruits that contain several seeds. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed areas. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies and traditional herbal medicine.
